page.title: 04ECOLOGY - KILMERSDON AREA
page.content: The disappearance of the hedgerow elm dramatically changed the landscape. Extensive replanting of deciduous trees by the Tree People and other groups, aided by fertile soil, high rainfall and springs that abound here. Lime-loving beeches are forming new avenues down Kilmersdon Hill and Charlton. Modern farming methods have brought their problems, particularly damage from chemical weed-killer sprays. Wild flowers common twenty years ago almost disappeared, lack of funds have reduced the use of controlling agents and as a result they are showing signs of recovery. Hedgerows shelter animal life (incl. shrews, rabbits, hedgehogs, weasels and stoats). There are birds in great variety including heron and plenty of the commoner sorts of butterflies.
